title: Offline & Online
abstract: Our e-commerce business needs a physical presence to engage with customers.
blogContent:
Our e-commerce business needs a physical presence to engage with customers. What should it be?

This was the question I was asked. Equipped with minimal knowledge about the industry and the brand, I ventured to explore the possibilities.

This is a hot topic. Whether it be eBay, Warby Parker, or Kate Spade, they're all trying to fuse the digital & the virtual. The company I’m doing my placement at, is asking the same question.

Over the course of 2 weeks I:

  • researched the industry
  • visited existing retail installations & stores
  • shadowed & interviewed retail salespeople
  • observed customers & users

WHAT TYPE OF PHYSICAL PRESENCE?

Any physical object or installation which interacts with the customer before he/she decides to purchace the product.

This definition spans a simple advertisement billboard, a street performance or a full-fledged store.



ISN’T INTERNET SHOPPING ENOUGH?

Sure. But it’s not all about shopping. For e-commerse businesses, I think it boils down to this:

  • "I want people to discover my brand"
  • "I want to strengthen the bond people have with my brand"

Having a physical presence can surely help. For 3 reasons:

  1. Human Contact
  2. Stronger impressions & experiences
  3. Testing / Touching the actual products

MY CONCLUSIONS

I figured there were 4 distinct possibilities. The major questions were whether the customer needed to test the product and if he/she needed to purchase it immediately after the interaction.

As a function of the team’s remarks, I then focused on two possibilities and drew up the 'rules' that should guide their implementation.


Examples:
  • TEST THE PRODUCT
  • SEE THE PRODUCT/BRAND
  • TEST THE PRODUCT & BUY IT
  • SEE THE PRODUCT & BUY IT

WHAT I LEARNT

This project was a great introduction to the company, the industry and the users. By giving me very little info, I had to start from scratch, with no pre-conceptions; from who the user is & what he/she wants. I can now start to understand how the company is trying to reply to these needs.

It’s crazy how much you can learn just by observing people. A couple of hours in a retail store suffice to discover a number of problems people are having. Sure, salespeople think you’re weird when you tell them that you just want to sit in a corner & look. But you gain invaluable insights. You see things that you couldn’t have imagined.

But it’s a double-edged sword. Starting with a tabula rasa introduces a lot of uncertainty. I was probably reinventing the wheel (Josh, the founder, has probably spent months reaching similar conclusions). It’s very difficult to start with a brief so wide and almost no info on branding.

But it’s probably the best way to start learning.
